However the definition of that was not something I always agreed with on wb...:) Cheers --[[User:Herbythyme|Herby]] [[User talk:Herbythyme|talk thyme]] 12:04, 19 June 2012 (UTC) : It looked like spam to me, too. --[[User:Pi zero|Pi zero]] ([[User talk:Pi zero|discuss]] • [[Special:Contributions/Pi zero|contribs]]) 13:38, 19 June 2012 (UTC) ::Thanks for taking care of it :) --[[User:Herbythyme|Herby]] [[User talk:Herbythyme|talk thyme]] 14:14, 19 June 2012 (UTC) ==Not sure== About [[Get GPS and data logging system for Motocross|this]]. To me it is spam but the editor seems legit? --[[User:Herbythyme|Herby]] [[User talk:Herbythyme|talk thyme]] 08:02, 24 June 2012 (UTC) :I think it is not spam, just someone who hasn't read [[Wikibooks:What is Wikibooks]] - tagged as a query (delayed deletion) for now [[User:QuiteUnusual|'''QU''']] [[User talk:QuiteUnusual|TalkQu]] 14:30, 24 June 2012 (UTC) The whole Sport Innovation things seems a little prone to promotional activity to me - finding [[Sport Innovation/Power Plate® powerBIKE™|this]] and [[Sport Innovation/Vibram FiveFingers Footwear/Enhancing Performance with Vibram FiveFinger|this]] for example. It's a while since I was a regular here though. --[[User:Herbythyme|Herby]] [[User talk:Herbythyme|talk thyme]] 10:39, 27 June 2012 (UTC) :yeah, it's pretty poor isn't it. Typical class project. We'll clean it out when the class is done! [[User:QuiteUnusual|'''QU''']] [[User talk:QuiteUnusual|TalkQu]] 14:23, 27 June 2012 (UTC) == Heading 3 == Hi, Thanks for cleaning up the A-Level Computing pages. I have a small concern though, as you are changing several of the heading 3s to heading 2s. The reason for using heading 3s is so the structure of the book will be represented when I bring all the pages together. Heading 2s will only appear on the final page that brings all the material together. take a look at: http://en.wikibooks.org/wiki/A-level_Computing/AQA/Print_version/Unit_2 to see what I mean. All other pages will use heading 3s as they sit under the heading 2s. Thanks [[User:Pluke|Pluke]] ([[User talk:Pluke|discuss]] • [[Special:Contributions/Pluke|contribs]]) 23:22, 24 June 2012 (UTC) :ah, okay, good point. I can reverse the ones I changed - when I'm back at a computer where I can use a bot I'll reverse the heading changes. Thanks for pointing it out. [[User:QuiteUnusual|'''QU''']] [[User talk:QuiteUnusual|TalkQu]] 07:22, 25 June 2012 (UTC) ::that would be greatm, the other changes were good though. Thanks [[User:Pluke|Pluke]] ([[User talk:Pluke|discuss]] • [[Special:Contributions/Pluke|contribs]]) 14:52, 25 June 2012 (UTC) == A question of references == In the [[Muggles' Guide to Harry Potter]], we have a number of places where we use statements made by the author on her web site. The problem is that Rowling has changed her web site, and the references are all now dead links. What is the preferred way of handling this? I can create references to archived copies of the pages using an external source like [http://archive.org The Wayback Machine], or I can put the specific text in a reference along with where and when it was collected. Which is preferable? [[User:Chazz|Chazz]] ([[User talk:Chazz|talk]]) 17:27, 27 June 2012 (UTC) :I often use the web archive (The Wayback Machine) for dead links as it permits the reader to benefit from the WEB linkage in case the information is related to what is being provided here, on the other hand if the information is only referential (not necessary beyond simply referential sourcing) then the last option may suffice as the link has no other intrinsic benefit. --[[User:Panic2k4|Panic]] ([[User talk:Panic2k4|discuss]] • [[Special:Contributions/Panic2k4|contribs]]) 17:43, 27 June 2012 (UTC) == I see the difference == I need to post my message on the talk page instead :) [[User:Planotse|Planotse]] ([[User talk:Planotse|discuss]] • [[Special:Contributions/Planotse|contribs]]) 12:41, 30 June 2012 (UTC) :Thanks, and I do think editors will find it useful too. [[User:QuiteUnusual|'''QU''']] [[User talk:QuiteUnusual|TalkQu]] 13:06, 30 June 2012 (UTC) == The Heill account == See the CU list - cheers. --[[User:Herbythyme|Herby]] [[User talk:Herbythyme|talk thyme]] 10:29, 7 July 2012 (UTC) == I see pattern accounts... == You might like to check my blocks of this am. Looking at the creation log there may be others. Cheers --[[User:Herbythyme|Herby]] [[User talk:Herbythyme|talk thyme]] 06:27, 12 July 2012 (UTC) :Thanks, I'll take a look [[User:QuiteUnusual|'''QU''']] [[User talk:QuiteUnusual|TalkQu]] 08:12, 12 July 2012 (UTC) == Inappropriate use of AWB in [[French]] Wikibook == I think many of your recent "corrections" to the [[French]] Wikibook are unreliable and unnecessary, as there are many words in French that are similar to English words but are spelled slightly differently. Conversion to the English spelling is not appropriate as these are not English words in the fist place. [[User:Recent Runes|Recent Runes]] ([[User talk:Recent Runes|discuss]] • [[Special:Contributions/Recent Runes|contribs]]) 18:36, 14 July 2012 (UTC) :Yeah, I saw that... just struggling with the children for an hour. I'll fix it now. [[User:QuiteUnusual|'''QU''']] [[User talk:QuiteUnusual|TalkQu]] 18:50, 14 July 2012 (UTC) ::I meant to say, I saw it happen as I clicked the button, meant to fix it straight away then got summoned away. Thanks for the couple you fixed, and the others should be done now too. I'll be more careful next time [[User:QuiteUnusual|'''QU''']] [[User talk:QuiteUnusual|TalkQu]] 18:54, 14 July 2012 (UTC) :::Great, thanks sorry if I was a bit "brusque". [[User:Recent Runes|Recent Runes]] ([[User talk:Recent Runes|discuss]] • [[Special:Contributions/Recent Runes|contribs]]) 19:21, 14 July 2012 (UTC) ::::Were you? I didn't notice...! Mind you, given what I hear from people over at Wikipedia you'd probably have to come round my house and punch me before I noticed. I genuinely appreciate things being pointed out to me - sometimes this place is so quiet that I reckon I could accidentally break half the project before someone spotted it, which isn't great. [[User:QuiteUnusual|'''QU''']] [[User talk:QuiteUnusual|TalkQu]] 19:23, 14 July 2012 (UTC) ---- Hello. I request renaming my following accounts: * محمد الجداوي → Avocato * GedawyBot → AvocatoBot * Confirmation link: [http://meta.wikimedia.org/w/index.php?title=User_talk%3A%D9%85%D8%AD%D9%85%D8%AF_%D8%A7%D9%84%D8%AC%D8%AF%D8%A7%D9%88%D9%8A&diff=3902291&oldid=3488161] * Reason: Privacy reasons '''Please''', delete all my userpages and talk pages of these accounts before renaming and I will create them later .Thanks in advance.--[[User:محمد الجداوي|M.Gedawy]] 07:40, 15 July 2012 (UTC) *All done [[User:QuiteUnusual|'''QU''']] [[User talk:QuiteUnusual|TalkQu]] 09:59, 15 July 2012 (UTC) == Transwiki vs Import == Thanks for the note about [[w:Geordie dialect words]]. This was my first attempt at moving something from one wiki to another, and it was extremely confusing. Can you explain what the difference between the two processes is? I'm still not very clear on it. [[User:Torchiest|Torchiest]] ([[User talk:Torchiest|discuss]] • [[Special:Contributions/Torchiest|contribs]]) 02:02, 17 August 2012 (UTC) :In the past it wasn't technically possible to automatically move content between projects. The Transwiki process is a legacy of this situation. It provided a way of manually tracking where the content had come from. Someone would paste the material into the Transwiki namespace, copy and paste the revision history onto the talk page, and then move the page into the mainspace. This meant you could link back to the redirect in the Transwiki namespace to find the talk page with the revision history. Now it is possible to import. This brings across the whole page and its history (usually, sometimes it can't all be moved for technical reasons) as if the page had been written here originally. This ensures all the original authors contributions can be seen in the page. To all intents and purposes the Transwiki process is obsolete and only used if an import can't be done. For example, if you wanted to bring across a page from the German Wikipedia and translate it, we'd have to use Transwiki instead of Import. All the main English projects, including Wikipedia and Wikiversity, can be imported. [[User:QuiteUnusual|'''QU''']] [[User talk:QuiteUnusual|TalkQu]] 07:36, 17 August 2012 (UTC) ::Thanks for your help. Now that the article is here, what would be the best thing to do at Wikipedia? Can I do a cross-wiki redirect? Or should I just have the page deleted? [[User:Torchiest|Torchiest]] ([[User talk:Torchiest|discuss]] • [[Special:Contributions/Torchiest|contribs]]) 21:35, 17 August 2012 (UTC) == should I undo moving templates == The templates were copied from Wikipedia: in particular NumBlk, EquationRef, EquationNote, and dependencies. Should I undo them. The other material is not copied from anywhere but my own computer. What is the copyright credit needed for wikipedia. [[User:Jamesmath|Jamesmath]] ([[User talk:Jamesmath|discuss]] • [[Special:Contributions/Jamesmath|contribs]]) 08:34, 17 August 2012 (UTC) :No need to undo anything, now I know where they came from I'll import the revision history - that deals with the attribution. Thanks for clarifying re. the other material. [[User:QuiteUnusual|'''QU''']] [[User talk:QuiteUnusual|TalkQu]] 12:00, 17 August 2012 (UTC) == Thanks for welcoming me to Wikibooks! == Now I have a question that I'm hoping you can help me with. I'm working on the handbook for WMF and we decided that the best place to put it is in Wikibooks. In Wikibooks it can be printed easily (because, technically, a handbook should go in one's hands), and we want it to be available for the public to view which goes along with the Foundation's general attitude of being as transparent as possible. I am creating a collection for the handbook including books on the Culture of Wikimedia, the importance of listening to the Wikipedia community, etc. A couple books in the collection will need to be locked because they contain legal policies which cannot be edited like employee time-off and legal US holidays, medical plans, etc. Is it possible to lock those books? --[[User:Smoify|Smoify]] ([[User talk:Smoify|discuss]] • [[Special:Contributions/Smoify|contribs]]) 19:54, 20 August 2012 (UTC) :The books can be fully protected so only administrators can edit them, yes. However, it rather goes against the core mission of Wikibooks to host uneditable material. Wouldn't you be better putting it on the Foundation wiki instead? [[User:QuiteUnusual|'''QU''']] [[User talk:QuiteUnusual|TalkQu]] 20:20, 20 August 2012 (UTC) We want to be able to print it easily, so that's why we chose Wikibooks. A copy will probably go on Foundation wiki, too. I'll look into if the Wikibook software can be installed on Foundation wiki. Thanks! --[[User:Smoify|Smoify]] ([[User talk:Smoify|discuss]] • [[Special:Contributions/Smoify|contribs]]) 21:41, 20 August 2012 (UTC) And.... we can create books on wikimediafoundation.org. Thanks so much for your help! --[[User:Smoify|Smoify]] ([[User talk:Smoify|discuss]] • [[Special:Contributions/Smoify|contribs]]) 21:45, 20 August 2012 (UTC) == How to create a link to a page in another wikibook? == Hi, i hope you can help me with this: i can't figure out how to create a link to a page in another book. For example, how do i link to this page? http://en.wikibooks.org/wiki/Engineering_Acoustics/Harmonic_Generation Thanks in advance. * A full link is created like this [[Engineering Acoustics/Harmonic Generation]]. If you are linking within a book, the approach is slightly different. [[User:QuiteUnusual|'''QU''']] [[User talk:QuiteUnusual|TalkQu]] 08:14, 30 August 2012 (UTC) ** Many thanks for your help. How can i display a word, say "harmonics", so that the page [[Engineering Acoustics/Harmonic Generation]] opens when the user clicks on the word? [[User:ByGrace|ByGrace]] ([[User talk:ByGrace|discuss]] • [[Special:Contributions/ByGrace|contribs]]) 14:36, 30 August 2012 (UTC) :I know that one. [[Engineering Acoustics/Harmonic Generation|Harmonics]] shows up as [[Engineering Acoustics/Harmonic Generation|Harmonics]] -- everything after the "|" is displayed. [[User:Chazz|Chazz]] ([[User talk:Chazz|talk]]) 15:16, 30 August 2012 (UTC) Many thanks for your help, Chazz. [[User:ByGrace|ByGrace]] ([[User talk:ByGrace|discuss]] • [[Special:Contributions/ByGrace|contribs]]) 03:07, 31 August 2012 (UTC) == Deleted link to the Visual Studio OpenGL Tutorial == Hi, I think, that the Blog I've mentioned is a good opportunity to show to beginners, how to get GLUT and GLEW installed on your Visual Studio programming environment. I know so many people that really NEED to know that, and are working with MS VS? The same time, almost nobody uses Code Blocks... so why delete the link to the blog? It makes sense to help people, does it not? And it took me many many hours, to get freeglut and glew installed and running on my computer with VS, so I thought I should prevent others from doing the same mistakes! So, please just leave it there for a few weeks, and if nobody is visiting the blog, I'll delete the link myself, I promisse :) ! How about that? == General cleanup == Just noting, I've been looking through the AWB cleanup on [[Wikijunior:Languages]], and so far I've found a couple of them that were wrong — where the thing being "corrected" was correct in context. One was  '''p''' in '''p'''ie  where the word-fragment "ie" was mistaken for a misrendering of "i.e.", and the other where the phonetic representation "nee" was mistaken for a misrendering of "née". These both seem typical of the sorts of unusual representations that arise in linguistic discussions. --[[User:Pi zero|Pi zero]] ([[User talk:Pi zero|discuss]] • [[Special:Contributions/Pi zero|contribs]]) 18:53, 13 September 2012 (UTC) :Ah, yes, sorry and thanks for fixing them... I spotted a couple and noted them to fix later but didn't get round to it. Didn't spot the "nee" though. [[User:QuiteUnusual|'''QU''']] [[User talk:QuiteUnusual|TalkQu]] 07:22, 14 September 2012 (UTC) ::Found one more like this that gave me a chuckle. At {{plainlinks|{{fullurl:Wikijunior:Languages/Quenya|curid=87833&diff=2407644&oldid=2407187}}|WJ:Languages/Quenya}}. --[[User:Pi zero|Pi zero]] ([[User talk:Pi zero|discuss]] • [[Special:Contributions/Pi zero|contribs]]) 12:10, 14 September 2012 (UTC) == Moving a page == Hi QU, thanks for your welcome message. How do i get permission to rename or move a page? [[User:Cheryl2012|Cheryl2012]] ([[User talk:Cheryl2012|discuss]] • [[Special:Contributions/Cheryl2012|contribs]]) 05:11, 27 September 2012 (UTC) :Pages are moved, not renamed. You gain the rights to move a page after your account becomes autoconfirmed which is usually after 10 edits and 4 days [[User:QuiteUnusual|'''QU''']] [[User talk:QuiteUnusual|TalkQu]] 07:01, 27 September 2012 (UTC) :: Hi QU, i have more than 100 edits and 40 days, but i still do not have the rights to move a page. Can pls help? [[User:Cheryl2012|Cheryl2012]] ([[User talk:Cheryl2012|discuss]] • [[Special:Contributions/Cheryl2012|contribs]]) 07:47, 27 September 2012 (UTC) ::: I have checked and your account is both autoconfirmed and has [[Wikibooks:Reviewer|reviewer]] rights so you do have permission to move pages. Can you tell me which page you are trying to move please? [[User:QuiteUnusual|'''QU''']] [[User talk:QuiteUnusual|TalkQu]] 15:35, 27 September 2012 (UTC) ::::Please forgive me for poking my nose in, but I just noticed that the "Move" command is hidden -- you have to click the down-arrow thing beside the "watch list" star before it will show the Move option. For me, that's the only thing there, makes it kinda silly... [[User:Chazz|Chazz]] ([[User talk:Chazz|talk]]) 16:45, 27 September 2012 (UTC) :::::If you are using the Vector skin, which is the default, then yes it is hidden in a dropdown list. Other skins, like Monobook, look different. Personally I find the other options all horrible, but clearly someone must like them! [[User:QuiteUnusual|'''QU''']] [[User talk:QuiteUnusual|TalkQu]] 17:05, 27 September 2012 (UTC) :::::: Many thanks for all the help. Most appreciated. [[User:Cheryl2012|Cheryl2012]] ([[User talk:Cheryl2012|discuss]] • [[Special:Contributions/Cheryl2012|contribs]]) 23:56, 27 September 2012 (UTC) == Talkback == {{Talkback|Byzantine95}} == Record == For The Record, this little...... event(if you so wish to call it that) will not go against me in anyway? --[[User:Byzantine95|Byzantine95]] ([[User talk:Byzantine95|discuss]] • [[Special:Contributions/Byzantine95|contribs]]) 17:45, 9 October 2012 (UTC) :Of course not. It was my error and nobody else will pay any attention to it. If they do, I will put them straight. Feel free to delete all that stuff from your talk page, or, if you prefer, I can actually delete it so nobody can see the previous discussion. [[User:QuiteUnusual|'''QU''']] [[User talk:QuiteUnusual|TalkQu]] 19:27, 9 October 2012 (UTC) I'll remove it, thank you.--[[User:Byzantine95|Byzantine95]] ([[User talk:Byzantine95|discuss]] • [[Special:Contributions/Byzantine95|contribs]]) 23:47, 9 October 2012 (UTC) == Re:Warning == Hiyas, Regarding that warning, It wasn't meant for anything. I was expecting to see a Twinkle like popup box with all the warnings like Wikipedia, but apparently not. --[[User:Byzantine95|Byzantine95]] ([[User talk:Byzantine95|discuss]] • [[Special:Contributions/Byzantine95|contribs]]) 23:50, 9 October 2012 (UTC)

revision.comment: Adding BookCat to uncategorised page
revision.text: The WBC hive is a double-skinned hive named after its inventor William Broughton Carr. Although it is presently used only by a minority of amateur beekeepers in the UK, it is the design that most people would immediately recognise as a wooden beehive, having a pitched roof, short legs, and multiple storeys with sloping sides, giving it a pagoda-like appearance. The WBC was one of the first designs to use the British Standard brood frame, and as such the frames it uses exactly the same frames as the more common "National" hive. A full WBC hive has the following components: * A pitched roof, typically covered with metal. The roof gables usually feature a cone escape to allow stray bees to escape, and this is often mistaken for the main entrance in illustrations. * Outer "lifts" with sloping sides. The lowest lift features a "porch" with "slides" which can be pushed across to block the entrance. * Inner boxes which are broadly similar to the "National" hive, but slightly narrower and made of thinner boards to a simpler design * A floor with short legs, usually splayed. The front back half of the floor is level, and the front half slopes downward and extends out beyond the lifts. The sloping floor creates a gap underneath the front edge of the brood box which forms the main entrance == Advantages == * The design is attractive * It is often argued that double-skinned hives like the WBC provide better insulation for the bees from hot and cold weather. However, this has not been proven by research * When disassembling the hive, the lifts can be used as a stand for the supers, keeping heavy lifting to a minimum == Disadvantages == The WBC is often dismissed as a "Victorian Monstrosity", for the some of the following reasons: * WBC Hives have more parts than other designs and some of them are complex and hard to manufacture, making it expensive * The hives are difficult to move, as the inner boxes are often not completely beetight and the entrance is hard to block. {{BookCat}}

page.title: Saylor.org's Ancient Civilizations of the World/The Hebrews

revision.comment: /* Attribution */
revision.text:
==The Hebrews or Israelites== [[File:Mosaic Tribes.jpg|thumb|Mosaic of the 12 Tribes of Israel. From a synagogue wall in Jerusalem.]]
Hebrews (עברים) is an ethnonym used in the Jewish Bible. It is mostly taken as synonymous with the Semitic Israelites. The Israelites (בני ישראל) were a Semitic Hebrew-speaking people of the Ancient Near East, who inhabited part of the Land of Canaan during the tribal and monarchic periods (15th to 6th centuries BCE), later evolving into Jews and Samaritans of the Hellenistic and Roman periods, inhabiting the territories of Judea and Galilee, and Samaria respectively, though a Jewish diaspora had already developed outside of Judea and Galilee. In Modern Hebrew usage, an Israelite is, broadly speaking, a lay member of the Jewish ethno-religious community, as opposed to the priestly orders of Kohanim and Levites.
The word "Israelite" derives from the Biblical Hebrew word "Israel". Although most literary references to Israelites are located in the Hebrew Bible, there is also abundant non-biblical archaeological and historical evidence of ancient Israel and Judah. The ethnonym is attested as early as the 13th century BCE in an Egyptian inscription. The Hebrew Bible etymologizes the name as from yisra "to prevail over" or "to struggle/wrestle with", and el, "God, the divine". The eponymous biblical patriarch of the Israelites is Jacob, who wrestled with God who gave him a blessing and renamed him "Israel" because he had "striven with God and with men, and have prevailed." (''Genesis'' 32:24-32) According to the Hebrew Bible, Israelites were the "chosen people" of God. The name Hebrews is sometimes used synonymously with "Israelites".
The biblical term "Israelites" (also the "Twelve Tribes" or "Children of Israel") means both the direct descendants of the patriarch Jacob (Israel) as well as the historical populations of the united Kingdom of Israel. For the post-exilic period, beginning in the 5th century BCE, the remnants of the Israelite tribes came to be referred to as Jews (tribes of Judah, Simeon and partially Benjamin and Levi), named for the kingdom of Judah. This change is explicit in the Book of Esther (4th century BCE). On the other hand, Samaritans (tribes of Menasseh, Ephraim and partially Benjamin and Levi) became named for Samaria. It replaced the title Children of Israel.
==History==
===Biblical Israelites===
The Torah traces the Israelites to the patriarch Jacob, grandson of Abraham, who was renamed Israel after a mysterious incident in which he wrestles all night with God (or an angel). Jacob's twelve sons (in order of birth), Reuben, Simeon, Levi, Judah, Dan, Naphtali, Gad, Asher, Issachar, Zebulun, Joseph and Benjamin, become the ancestors of twelve tribes, with the exception of Joseph, whose two sons Mannasseh and Ephraim become tribal eponyms. [[File:12 Tribes of Israel Map.svg|left|thumb|Map of the twelve tribes of Israel.]]
Jacob and his sons are forced by famine to go down into Egypt. When they arrive they and their families are 70 in number, but within four generations they have increased to 600,000 men of fighting age, and the Pharaoh of Egypt, alarmed, first enslaves them and then orders the death of all male Hebrew children. The God of Israel reveals his name to Moses, a Hebrew of the line of Levi; Moses leads the Israelites out of bondage and into the desert, where God gives them their laws and the Israelites agree to become his people. Nevertheless, the Israelites lack complete faith in God, and the generation which left Egypt is not permitted to enter the Promised Land. [[File:C+B-Egypt-Fig15-KarnakPlaceListCartouches.PNG|thumb|Description of Israelite captives from the kingdoms of Israel and Judea, as they were portrayed on the Southern wall of Shoshenq I's Temple of Amun in Karnak (dated 925/6 BCE).]]
Following the death of the generation of Moses a new generation, led by Joshua, enters Canaan and takes possession of the land in accordance with the curse placed upon Canaan by Noah. Yet even now the Israelites lack strength in God in the face of the peoples of the land, and periods of weakness and backsliding alternate with periods of resilience under a succession of Judges. Eventually the Israelites ask for a king, and God gives them Saul. David, the youngest (divinely favored) son of Jesse of Bethlehem would succeed Saul. Under David the Israelites establish the kingdom of God, and under David's son Solomon they build the Temple where God takes his earthly dwelling among them. Yet Solomon sins by allowing his foreign wives to worship their own gods, and so on his death and reign of his son, Rehoboam, the kingdom is divided in two.
The kings of the northern kingdom of Israel are uniformly bad, permitting the worship of other gods and failing to enforce the worship of God alone, and so God eventually allows them to be conquered and dispersed among the peoples of the earth; in their place strangers settle the northern land. In Judah some kings are good and enforce the worship of God alone, but many are bad and permit other gods, even in the Temple itself, and at length God allows Judah to fall to her enemies, the people taken into captivity in Babylon, the land left empty and desolate, and the Temple itself destroyed.
Yet despite these events God does not forget his people, but sends Cyrus, king of Persia as his messiah to deliver them from bondage. The Israelites are allowed to return to Judah and Benjamin, the Temple is rebuilt, the priestly orders restored, and the service of sacrifice resumed. Through the offices of the sage Ezra, Israel is constituted as a holy community, bound by the Law and holding itself apart from all other peoples.
===Historical Israelites=== [[File:Merneptah Israel Stele Cairo.JPG|thumb|The Merneptah stele (JE 31408), bearing the first record of the name Israel (Cairo Museum).]]
In contrast to the Biblical account, it became clear by the 1920s that the idea of an Israelite conquest of Canaan - the story of the book of Joshua - was not supported by the archaeological record. The response of the time was to propose that the main biblical idea was still correct, but that the Israelites entered Canaan peacefully instead of through conquest. Later, this compromise was abandoned, and the Israelites were interpreted to be indigenous Canaanites. The revision of Israelite origins has implications for Israelite religion: whereas the Bible had depicted them as monotheists from the beginning, the new understanding is that they were polytheists who harboured a small and ultimately successful group of monotheistic revolutionaries.
The name Israel first appears c. 1209 BCE, at the end of the Late Bronze Age and the very beginning of the period archaeologists and historians call Iron Age I, in an inscription of the Egyptian pharaoh Merneptah. The inscription is very brief and says simply: "Israel is laid waste and his seed is not". The hieroglyph accompanying the name "Israel" indicates that it refers to a people, most probably located in the highlands of Samaria. Over the next two hundred years (the period of Iron Age I) the number of highland villages increased from 25 to over 300 and the settled population doubled to 40,000. There is general agreement that the majority of the population living in these villages was of Canaanite origin. By the 10th century BCE a rudimentary state had emerged in the north-central highlands, and in the 9th century this became a kingdom. The kingdom was sometimes called Israel by its neighbours, but more frequently it was known as the "House (or Land) of Omri." Settlement in the southern highlands was minimal from the 12th through the 10th centuries BCE, but a state began to emerge there in the 9th century, and from 850 BCE onward a series of inscriptions are evidence of a kingdom which its neighbours refer to as the "House of David."
===The rise of the Jews===
Jews (יְהוּדִים‎), also known as the Jewish people, are an ethno-religious group originating from the Israelites or Hebrews. According to the ''Books of Chronicles,'' chapter 9 line 2, the Israelites, who took part in The Return to Zion were from the Tribe of Judah alongside the tribes of Simeon, Benjamin, Levi, Ephraim and Manasseh, which were absorbed into it.
After the Persian conquest of Babylon in 539, Judah became a province of the Persian empire. This status continued into the following Hellenistic period, when Yehud became a disputed province of Ptolemaic Egypt and Seleucid Syria. In the early part of the 2nd century BCE, a revolt against the Seleucids led to the establishment of an independent Jewish kingdom under the Hasmonean dynasty. The Hasmoneans adopted a deliberate policy of imitating and reconstituting the Davidic kingdom, and as part of this forcibly converted to Judaism their neighbours in the Land of Israel. The conversions included Nabateans (Zabadeans) and Itureans, the peoples of the former Philistine cities, the Moabites, Ammonites and Edomites. Attempts were also made to incorpoarate the Samaritans, following takeover of Samaria. The success of mass-conversions is however questionable, as most groups retained their tribal separations and mostly turned Hellenistic or Christian, with Edomites perhaps being the only exception to merge into the Jewish society under Herodian dynasty and in the following period of Jewish-Roman Wars. While there are some references to maintaining the tribal separation among Israelites during the Hasmonean period, the dominant position of the tribe of Judah as well as nationalistic policies of Hasmoneans to refer to residents of Hasmonean Judea as Jews practically erased the tribal distinction, with the exception of the priestly orders of Levites and Kohanim (tribe of Levi).
The Babylonian Jewish community, though maintaining permanent ties with the Hasmonean and later Herodian kingdoms, evolved into a separate Jewish community, which during the Talmudic period assembled its own practices-the Babylonian Talmud, slightly differing from the Jerusalem Talmud. The Babylonian Jewry is considered to be the predecessor of most Mizrachi Jewish communities.
==Attribution== "The Israelites" (Wikipedia) http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Israelites {{BookCat}}

revision.comment: Created page with "Watergate Salad came about in history at about the same time as the Watergate scandal. At the time, my mother heard this recipe on a local radio program, and on that program ..."
revision.text: Watergate Salad came about in history at about the same time as the Watergate scandal. At the time, my mother heard this recipe on a local radio program, and on that program (The Good Neighbor Show), they explained how the name came about. It was pretty simple. The basic premise was that government is filled with nuts and fruit, and with those involved in the Watergate scandal being the symbol of governmental craziness at its best, the name of this salad full of fruit and nuts was an oblique reference to the political atmosphere as perceived by the populace at that time in history.----

I hold '''Bachelor of Engineering in Automobile''' and '''Master of Business Administration -Industry Integrated'''. I have '''4.67 years of experience'''. I have completed my schooling in Dubai and lived here for 16 years. I was working at Deloitte-US in India. I was working in the company as an Analyst – Operations (Strategy, Research & Innovation). My responsibilities for this job was to conduct research, develop strategies for the client related to Industries-sectors like Automobile, Aeronautics, Marine, Steel & Metals. Before this, I have worked for Nissan Motors India. I started my career in the company as a Sales Advisor (Intern) and was promoted to Sales Executive and later to Brand Development Executive. My responsibility in the job was to expand the marketing capability to widen the range of customers to increase the product portfolio. == '''Education''' == * M.B.A - Industry Integrated
* B.E (Automobile Engineering)
* Completed 10th and 12th from Dubai (Completed schooling in Dubai)
== '''Significant Achievement''' == * Design and development of intelligent A/C system for the vehicle
* Letter of Appreciation during M.B.A
* Campus placement at Deloitte-US in India (After M.B.A)
* Completed internship at REVA Electric Car Company (India)
* Completed internship in Product marketing and sales for ArcelorMittal – D.S.T.C (Dubai)
* Best performer award for the Industries team in Deloitte
== '''Continuous Professional Development''' == * Master Diploma in CAD
* Diploma in Product Design & Manufacturing Process
* Diploma in Operations Management
